4. Fiscal Efficiency and Resilience
• Elevated modular homes in the project are 40–50% less costly per unit to build than traditional site-built
homes in comparable flood-prone areas.
• Incorporating solar, rain catchment, and aquaponics reduces long-term utility loads—saving residents
hundreds annually and lightening city utility infrastructure pressure.
• By concentrating housing, jobs, and nature-based infrastructure in one site, the project will generate
ongoing tax revenue while reducing municipal exposure to flood response and emergency costs.
Public-Private Partnership & MOU Strategy
A formal Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the development team, the City of Hattiesburg, and
Forrest County will formalize shared responsibilities, streamline regulatory coordination, and unlock multi-level
funding. This agreement will serve as a roadmap for delivering infrastructure, housing affordability, and long-term
community benefits—while de-risking implementation for all parties.

Establishing the MOU will help the City and County:
• Capture competitive federal and state grants by demonstrating shovel-readiness and intergovernmental
alignment
• Avoid siloed permitting or piecemeal reviews, accelerating infrastructure and housing delivery
• Ensure affordability benchmarks, equity safeguards, and maintenance responsibilities are clearly assigned
and transparent
• Maximize return on ARPA and CDBG dollars, with housing and public infrastructure that will serve the
region for decades
Partner Key Contributions
City of Hattiesburg CUP/PUD approvals, zoning and land-use alignment, ARPA allocation, fee waivers,

marina grading, and trail integration coordination

Forrest County CDBG infrastructure funding, drainage engineering, HOME/ESG applications,

construction staging and public access easements
